io.artframework

extends ArtProvider, FactoryProvider<TriggerFactory>

        static TriggerProvider of(Scope scope)
        Creates a new default implementation of this trigger provider using the given configuration.
        Specified by:
        of in interface ArtProvider
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • add

        TriggerProvider add(@NonNull
                    @NonNull ArtObjectMeta<Trigger> triggerInformation)
        Registers a new trigger using the provided information.

        This will call ArtObjectMeta.initialize() if the information is not initialized and will fail silently if there are any exceptions. Using add(Class) or add(Trigger) is preferred since it will handle all the dirty work for you.

        Parameters:
        triggerInformation - the information of the trigger you want to register
        Returns:
        this trigger provider

      • add

        TriggerProvider add(java.lang.Class<? extends Trigger> triggerClass)
        Registers a new trigger extracting the needed information from the given class.

        This will scan the given class for any ART annotations and uses that information to register the trigger contained within that class. All methods that are not annotated will be ignored. You can also annotate the class if you only have one trigger method.

        It will not try instantiate the class or setup any listening for the trigger defined inside it.

        You can also use the add(Trigger) method as an alternative to this.

        Parameters:
        triggerClass - the trigger class that should be used to extract the required information
        Returns:
        this trigger provider

      • add

        <TTrigger extends Trigger> TriggerProvider add(java.lang.Class<TTrigger> triggerClass,
                                               ArtObjectProvider<TTrigger> supplier)
        Registers a new trigger with the given supplier as factory.

        This will scan the given class for any ART annotations and uses that information to register the trigger contained within that class. All methods that are not annotated will be ignored. You can also annotate the class if you only have one trigger method.

        It will use the provided supplier for every instatiation of the trigger. This may happen multiple times during the livecycle of the art-framework. Make sure you implement the AutoCloseable interface if you need to release any resources.

        You can also use the add(Trigger) method as an alternative to this.

        Type Parameters:
        TTrigger - the type of the trigger
        Parameters:
        triggerClass - the trigger class that should be used to extract the required information
        supplier - the supplier that will be used to create new instances of the trigger
        Returns:
        this trigger provider

      • add

        TriggerProvider add(Trigger trigger)
        Registers a new trigger extracting the needed information from the given trigger instance.

        This will scan the trigger object for any ART annotations and uses that information to register the trigger contained within that class. All methods that are not annotated will be ignored. You can also annotate the class if you only have one trigger method.

        You can also use the add(Class) method as an alternative to this.

        Parameters:
        trigger - the trigger object that should be used to extract the required information
        Returns:
        this trigger provider

      • trigger

        CombinedResult trigger(java.lang.String identifier,
                       TriggerTarget<?>... targets)
        Triggers the trigger that matches the given identifier or has an alias that matches it.

        Will return a CombinedResult that contains all information about the execution of the Trigger and all of its child executions and checks. This may be in the future since trigger execution may be delayed.

        The result will never be null even if there are no trigger with the given identifier. A result that had no trigger will be empty instead. Use Result.status() to check that.

        Parameters:
        identifier - the identifier or alias of the trigger
        targets - the trigger targets that wrap a predicate
        Returns:
        the result that contains the outcome of the trigger
